title: What is the next step in determining if life was found in Venus’s atmosphere? How long will it take? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Life” is NOT found in Venus’ atmosphere. What was found is a gas (phosphine) that on Earth is associated with a certain kind of bacteria. But there are other ways to make phosphine. Here on Earth, we make quite a lot of it in chemical plants using a process that starts with phosphoric acid. The next step is for a second group to observe phosphine in Venus’ atmosphere and hopefully using some different methods that can see more than just one spectral band. After the presence of phosphine is confirmed, then the theorists can come up with a list of possible sources. One possibility is that this gas is made deep underground where there is an abundance of heat and pressure using a geochemical process not unlike what we use in chemical plants. This is FAR more likely than a biological source. After you have some competing theories then you have to think of observations or experiments you could do to rule out some of the theories. We are not there yet but this is the next step, thinking of ways to rule-out some of the possible sources. One thing about life is that it is always going to be part of some ecosystem. You can’t have just one organism. It is hard to imagine a complex ecosystem living in 900-degree heat in a cloud of sulfuric acid. More likely the phosphine is made underground then leaks upward. But first, we need to verify it is actually there.

Observations at two different observatories have confirmed the presence of Phosphine gas in Venus’ atmosphere. As far as we know, this gas can only be produced by life, under the conditions in Venus atmosphere. Additional, independent confirmation of this finding is desirable. The ESA/JAXA probe BepiColobo will pass near Venus on October 15th. They will attempt at that time to detect Phosphine, and again in August, 2021, when the probe will pass even closer to our sister planet. It’s not clear how long it will take to analyze this, or other data relating to Phosphine on Venus. The work done to detect the gas in the first place took several years.

A previous Venus probe identified a chemical (gas) that is associated with living organisms - but not exclusively. One approach might be to try to eliminate other possible natural sources of this compound. The will probably also include instruments in the next probe that seek to identify other ‘markers’ of organic organisms. There will be several fly-by missions (en route to other planets) that may be able to contribute some measurements, but the orbiter-lander missions now being discussed won’t be operational for at least several more years.

The lifeforms producing phosphine would need to live on the ground, if not underground to have access to phosphorus compounds! And they would need to access to water to be able to produce it. Most probable outcome is that that phosphine origin is abiogenic just like methane is produced also by abiogenic way on earth and most probably also on Mars. A two-prong approach is likely. Gather more data to better determine the amount of phosphine, look for any variation with depth or temperature in the atmosphere, and look for seasonal effects. Also pursue studies of alternative ways of producing phosphine under the conditions that exist on Venus.

I would think that it will be some time before anything can be ascertained about this. The problem being that the planet Venus is so toxic to everything, nothing can survive for long either on the surface of the planet or in the planets atmosphere, human or robotic.

Firstly, only phosphine was found in an amount in the atmosphere which is hard to explain by anything other than life. However, it’s still not “hard” evidence. The next step is to figure out what could produce that much posphine.
There’s no “next step”. No life form has ever been found on Venus, nor will there ever be—-too inhospitable for life.
